content:
In this first lecture you will get a gentle introduction to the statistical programming language R and some of its basic functionality. The lecture covers different operators, the idea behind R’s workhorse functions, and basic data structures in R. The lecture is a bit abstract, like this line of code:
(I_am_an_object <- seq(from = 2, to = 8)) # [1] 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 But stay with it, you’ll get the hang of it soon enough. You will also learn about the workflow of using RStudio, including how to set up a project and how to use R Scripts to organize your research and make it reproducible.
Lecture slides: Int_R_oduction
Today’s exercise: Web Excercise 1
summary: In this first lecture you will get a gentle introduction to the statistical programming language R and some of its basic functionality.
title: 1 Hello R: Vectors

content:
This lecture will introduce you to data frames and tibbles, and how to work with them as well as with atomic vectors. We will also cover packages - the source of R’s versatility - and get to know basic functionality from the collection of packages known as tidyverse. A set of packages containing, among others, data of Star Wars characters:

content:
This lecture introduces you to the basics of “the grammar of graphics”, the guiding idea of the R package ggplot2. You will gain a basic understanding of how to visualize your data for exploratory purposes. In particular, you will be able to read and write R code such as the one below, which produces the figure shown beneath the code.
Lecture slides: Visualization I
Today’s exercise: Web Excercise 3
ggplot(data = ESS, mapping = aes(y = imwbcnt, x = factor(eduyrs), weight = pspwght)) + geom_boxplot() + geom_smooth(mapping = aes(group = 1)) + labs(y = "Immigrants make country \n worse place to live", x = "Years of Education") + theme_minimal() Homework and further readings Finish web exercise 1 through 3.
summary: This lecture will introduce you to the basics of the grammar of graphics and ggplot2.
title: 3 Visualization I
